Award.AwardTitle: Nonlocal interaction equations and applications to collective motion of individuals
Award.AbstractNarration:
Nonlocal interaction equations are continuum models for large systems of particles where every particle can interact not only with its immediate neighbors but also with particles far away. In biology, they arise as model for the movement of large swarms of individuals (insects, bacteria, birds, fish, etc...). The research will involve rigorous analysis of nonlinear partial differential equations, numerical simulations, and modeling. More specifically the following problems will be investigated: 1) Study of the formation of singularities and the formation of patterns in nonlocal interaction equations. 2) Study of nonlocal interaction equations in a domain with boundaries and use of optimal transport techniques in order to study phenomena of mass concentration on the boundaries (such phenomena are observed, for example, in continuum models for swarms of locusts). 3) Modeling of the formation of "foraging trails'' in an ant colony.

This project investigates equations describing the collective behavior of a large number of individuals, such as a swarm of insects, a flock of birds, a school of fish, or a colony of bacteria. Understanding basic rules of these swarming behaviors has potential for the design of flexible and robust algorithms for unmanned vehicles, with possible applications, for example, to the surveillance of hazardous areas. The equations investigated in this research also arise in various other contexts: evolution of vortex densities in superconductors, adhesion dynamics, simplified model for granular flow and orientational distribution of filaments in cells.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: Understanding how large numbers of particles interact with one another in order to reach a specific configuration or  specific dynamics is an important problem  in  material  and biological sciences. In material sciences one is typically interested in the self-assembly of particles, nano-particles, or molecules. The goal is to understand what type of interaction rules between the particles leads to what type of structure. In biological sciences, the emergence of collective behavior in large groups of individuals belonging to a social aggregate  (e.g. swarms of insects, flocks of birds, schools of fish, colonies of bacteria) has recently drawn much interest from the scientific community. Simple interaction laws between individuals can lead to the emergence of  surprisingly complex patterns and dynamics at the level of the swarm. The PI and collaborators have conducted a thorough investigation of  emerging structures in large systems of interacting particles. The research has many new theoretical results that address 1) the formation of singularities, 2) the stability of patterns, 3) the dimensionality of emerging structures and 4) the regularity of solutions. For example, the PI and collaborators have shown that the dimensionality of the emerging structure depends on the singularity of the potential that governs the interaction between the particles. The research has also produced a new mathematical model for the formation of "foraging trails'' in an ant colony. Finally, the PI and collaborators have discovered connections between the study of self-organization in large systems of particles and data mining/machine learning. As a consequence, they have developed state of the art algorithms for data clustering and community detection.


Border Impact: The work has involved the training of undergraduate students in applied differential equations, scientific computing and machine learning.
